parts.text:
```xml
<output>
<analysis>
<has-cmf>False. There is no CMF number present in the provided post information.</has-cmf>
<refers-to-candidate>False. While the post promotes voting, it does not explicitly mention any specific parliamentary candidate by name or party affiliation from the provided list. The post is in Hungarian, and focuses on the importance of the Hungarian community voting.</refers-to-candidate>
<addresses-the-wide-population>True. The post is a paid advertisement on Facebook, a public platform, and its message is clearly intended to reach a wide audience, specifically the Hungarian-speaking population in Romania.</addresses-the-wide-population>
<electoral-objective>True. The primary objective of the post is to encourage voting. While it doesn't explicitly endorse a specific candidate, the implicit message is to participate in the election, which could indirectly benefit certain parties representing the Hungarian minority.  The phrasing "Azért szavazok, mert rajtam múlik, hogy lesz-e a magyaroknak képviselete" (I vote because it depends on me whether Hungarians will have representation) strongly suggests an electoral objective.</electoral-objective>
<journalism>False. The post lacks the objectivity and neutrality expected of journalistic content. It's a clear call to action, urging voters to participate in the election, which goes beyond simply informing the public.</journalism>
<personal_opinion>False. The post presents a viewpoint intended to persuade voters, not simply express a personal opinion. The language used is emotive and persuasive, aiming to mobilize a specific segment of the electorate.</personal_opinion>
</analysis>

<conclusion>
<post_id>1112562726903906</post_id>
<electoral-propaganda-analysis>
The Facebook post, while not explicitly mentioning specific candidates, constitutes electoral propaganda. It targets a specific demographic (Hungarian speakers in Romania) and urges them to vote, implicitly suggesting that their participation is crucial for the representation of their community.  The paid nature of the post, its broad reach, and its persuasive language all point towards an intention to influence the election outcome. The timing of the post, close to election day, further strengthens this interpretation.  While it doesn't directly violate Article 36 (7) - a) by naming a candidate, it does fulfill criteria b) (used during the electoral campaign), c) (has an electoral objective), and arguably d) (goes beyond simple journalistic information).  The argument that it's simply encouraging civic participation is weak given the targeted nature and persuasive language used.
</electoral-propaganda-analysis>
<electoral-propaganda-decision>TRUE</electoral-propaganda-decision>
<electoral-propaganda-candidates>
  <candidate><name>None explicitly mentioned</name><impact>POSITIVE (indirectly benefits parties representing Hungarian interests)</impact></candidate>
</electoral-propaganda-candidates>
<responsible-party-or-group>RMDSZ</responsible-party-or-group>
<message-for-police>
RMDSZ, pentru încălcarea articolului 98 t) din LEGEA nr. 208 din 20 iulie 2015, prin publicarea unei postări plătite pe Facebook (ID postare: 1112562726903906), după ora 18:00 pe 23.11.2024, care îndeamnă la vot într-un mod persuasiv, vizând în mod specific comunitatea maghiară din România.  Postarea, deși nu menționează candidați anumiți, are un efect electoral clar, având ca obiectiv mobilizarea electoratului maghiar. Fraze precum „Azért szavazok, mert rajtam múlik, hogy lesz-e a magyaroknak képviselete” (I vote because it depends on me whether Hungarians will have representation) demonstrează intenția de a influența votul.  Chemarea la acțiune, combinată cu bugetul alocat (RON 100-199) și numărul mare de impresii (10K-15K), confirmă natura propagandistică a postării, încălcând astfel prevederile legale.  Contact: kommunikacio@rmdsz.ro, +40742125468.
</message-for-police>
</conclusion>
</output>
```
